G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this civil action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interest and costs.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2, and 8.proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester County pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, and 8 because the cause of action arose in Worcester County and the Premises where Plaintiff was injured is located at 123 Maple Street, Worcester, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3.proposition: Personal jurisdiction over Defendant is proper because she resides in Massachusetts and/or regularly conducts activities and owns real property in Massachusetts, and the claims asserted arise from such activities and ownership.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707\.raw_text: *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707–08 (1973) (abolishing common‑law distinctions between invitees and licensees and imposing a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors)
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707\.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a lawful visitor and business invitee on the Premises, a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the Premises, including the abutting sidewalk and walkway used by tenants and invitees, in a reasonably safe condition and to protect Plaintiff against unreasonable risks of harm of which Defendant knew or reasonably should have known. See *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707–08 (1973) (abolishing common‑law distinctions between invitees and licensees and imposing a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors); *Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739, 743–44 (1995) (landowner owes duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors).
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707\.support_reasoning: The quoted passage is a concurrence in Mounsey criticizing the continued special treatment of trespassers, but the case itself (in the majority at 363 Mass. 707–08) expressly abolishes the distinction between invitees and licensees and adopts a general duty of reasonable care owed by landowners to all lawful visitors. Thus, while the excerpt provided does not itself recite the rule, the cited case as a whole is correctly used for the proposition that a landowner/occupier owes a duty of reasonable care to lawful visitors such as business invitees.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707\.relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors.

*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.raw_text: *Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739, 743–44 (1995) (landowner owes duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors)
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a lawful visitor and business invitee on the Premises, a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the Premises, including the abutting sidewalk and walkway used by tenants and invitees, in a reasonably safe condition and to protect Plaintiff against unreasonable risks of harm of which Defendant knew or reasonably should have known. See *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707–08 (1973) (abolishing common‑law distinctions between invitees and licensees and imposing a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors); *Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739, 743–44 (1995) (landowner owes duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors).
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly restates the general Massachusetts rule that a landowner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors and that this duty includes maintaining the premises in a reasonably safe condition and warning of unreasonable dangers. Although the case ultimately holds there is no duty to alter an adjacent state highway, the cited portion (420 Mass. at 743–44) squarely supports the proposition that landowners owe a duty of reasonable care to lawful visitors/business invitees on their premises, including with respect to reasonably safe conditions and known risks.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825, 827 (1994), citing Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973). This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.” (420 Mass. at 743–44).

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.raw_text: *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass. 368, 378–83 (2010) (property owners owe duty of reasonable care as to all accumulations of snow and ice and may be liable for failure to act reasonably in response to hazards from snow and ice)
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: Defendant also owed Plaintiff a duty to act as a reasonably prudent person would under the circumstances in removing or treating snow and ice on the Premises and in not creating or exacerbating dangerous conditions through her snow removal efforts. See *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass. 368, 378–83 (2010) (property owners owe duty of reasonable care as to all accumulations of snow and ice and may be liable for failure to act reasonably in response to hazards from snow and ice); *Sullivan v. Brookline*, 435 Mass. 353, 357–58 (2001) (duty to exercise reasonable care in snow and ice removal).
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that property owners owe lawful visitors a general duty of reasonable care with respect to all hazards arising from snow and ice, explicitly abolishing the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction. It further explains that this duty includes acting as a reasonable person under all the circumstances in snow and ice removal, and criticizes earlier case law suggesting that negligent snow removal efforts that increase risk would not create liability, thereby supporting the idea that an owner may be liable for creating or exacerbating dangerous conditions through snow removal efforts.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’… If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

*Sullivan v. Brookline*, 435 Mass. 353,.raw_text: *Sullivan v. Brookline*, 435 Mass. 353, 357–58 (2001) (duty to exercise reasonable care in snow and ice removal)
*Sullivan v. Brookline*, 435 Mass. 353,.proposition: Defendant also owed Plaintiff a duty to act as a reasonably prudent person would under the circumstances in removing or treating snow and ice on the Premises and in not creating or exacerbating dangerous conditions through her snow removal efforts. See *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass. 368, 378–83 (2010) (property owners owe duty of reasonable care as to all accumulations of snow and ice and may be liable for failure to act reasonably in response to hazards from snow and ice); *Sullivan v. Brookline*, 435 Mass. 353, 357–58 (2001) (duty to exercise reasonable care in snow and ice removal).
*Sullivan v. Brookline*, 435 Mass. 353,.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns reinstatement and retraining of a disabled police retiree under Massachusetts retirement and civil service statutes. It does not involve premises liability, snow and ice conditions, or a duty of care in snow and ice removal. Citing this case for a duty to act as a reasonably prudent person in removing or treating snow and ice, or for creating/exacerbating dangerous conditions through snow removal efforts, is inaccurate and unsupported by the text or holding.
*Sullivan v. Brookline*, 435 Mass. 353,.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that G. L. c. 32, § 8 (2), compels reinstatement of retired employees once properly cleared by the retirement board, and a vacancy exists; however, G. L. c. 31, § 39, requires retirees who have been away from the job for ‘a period of time greater than five years’ to complete a retraining program before they are entitled to return to full employment.”

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.raw_text: *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146–47 (2006) (quoting Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281)
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.proposition: Pursuant to the general negligence standard recognized in Massachusetts, Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty “to conform to a certain standard of conduct for the protection of others against unreasonable risks.” *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146–47 (2006) (quoting Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281).
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly sets out the elements of negligence under Massachusetts law and, in doing so, cites Restatement (Second) of Torts provisions that define negligent conduct in terms of an actor’s duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid unreasonable risks of physical harm to others. While the quoted pages focus on duty and foreseeability, they clearly adopt the general negligence framework in which a defendant has a duty to conform to a standard of reasonable conduct for the protection of others against unreasonable risks, consistent with Restatement § 281. Thus the case is properly cited for this general duty formulation.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage.… We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ See Remy v. MacDonald, supra at 677, citing Restatement (Second) Torts § 302 comment a (1965).”

*Cottam v. CVS Pharmacy*, 436 Mass. 316,.raw_text: *Cottam v. CVS Pharmacy*, 436 Mass. 316, 323–25 (2002) (recognizing liability where a party voluntarily undertakes a duty and performs it negligently)
*Cottam v. CVS Pharmacy*, 436 Mass. 316,.proposition: Defendant further owed Plaintiff a duty, once she voluntarily undertook snow removal on the walkway, to perform that undertaking with reasonable care, and not to leave the walkway in a more dangerous condition than if she had done nothing. See *Cottam v. CVS Pharmacy*, 436 Mass. 316, 323–25 (2002) (recognizing liability where a party voluntarily undertakes a duty and performs it negligently); Restatement (Second) of Torts § 323 (negligent performance of an undertaking to render services necessary for the protection of another).
*Cottam v. CVS Pharmacy*, 436 Mass. 316,.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly adopts Restatement (Second) of Torts § 323 and reiterates that “a duty voluntarily assumed must be performed with due care,” recognizing liability for negligent performance of a voluntary undertaking. While the facts concern a pharmacy’s warnings rather than snow removal, the legal principle is the same: once a party undertakes services necessary for another’s protection, it must exercise reasonable care and may be liable if its negligence increases the risk of harm or causes harm through reliance. Thus the case supports the general voluntary-undertaking duty proposition cited.
*Cottam v. CVS Pharmacy*, 436 Mass. 316,.relevant_excerpt: “A pharmacy, like any other person or entity, may voluntarily assume a duty that would not otherwise be imposed on it, and thus may voluntarily assume a duty to provide information, advice or warnings to its customers. Massachusetts recognizes that ‘a duty voluntarily assumed must be performed with due care,’ and we have approved the principles pertaining to voluntary assumption of a duty as set forth in the Restatement (Second) of Torts § 323 (1965).… ‘If a person voluntarily assumes a duty or undertakes to render services to another that should have been seen as necessary for her protection, that person may be liable for harm caused because of the negligent performance of his undertaking.’”

*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.raw_text: *Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 154–56 (2013) (landowner liable where actions create or enhance an obvious risk)
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.proposition: Defendant’s conduct in creating and/or allowing a known sheet of ice to persist on the primary walkway used by tenants and visitors constitutes a breach of the duty of reasonable care under Massachusetts law. See *Papadopoulos*, 457 Mass. at 383–84 (liability for failure to act reasonably with respect to snow and ice); *Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 154–56 (2013) (landowner liable where actions create or enhance an obvious risk).
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a Massachusetts landowner’s duty of reasonable care is not eliminated merely because a danger is open and obvious, where the landowner has created and maintained the condition and can or should anticipate that lawful entrants will encounter it despite the risk. While the facts involve a trampoline and shallow pool rather than ice, the court expressly relies on Papadopoulos and Soederberg (snow-and-ice walkway cases) to reaffirm that a landowner may be liable for creating or maintaining an obvious hazard in an area the owner knows people will use. Thus, it substantively supports the proposition that creating or allowing a known dangerous condition on a primary walkway can constitute a breach of reasonable care under Massachusetts law.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.relevant_excerpt:
“A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’ Papadopoulos, supra, quoting Soederberg…

‘While the open and obvious doctrine may relieve the defendant of its duty to warn, the doctrine does not mean that the defendant can maintain its property “in an unreasonably unsafe condition as long as the unsafe condition is open and obvious.”’ … On these facts, a jury were entitled to conclude that the defendants owed a duty of care — specifically a duty to remedy — despite the open and obvious nature of the danger.”

*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.raw_text: *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973) (liability where defendant had actual or constructive notice of dangerous condition and failed to remedy within a reasonable time)
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.proposition: Defendant’s failure to respond reasonably to repeated tenant complaints and photographic evidence of the hazardous condition further demonstrates a breach of her duty to exercise reasonable care. See *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973) (liability where defendant had actual or constructive notice of dangerous condition and failed to remedy within a reasonable time); *Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc.*, 332 Mass. 560, 563 (1955) (duty to remedy known hazard on premises).
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.support_reasoning: Oliveri is a premises-liability slip-and-fall case focused on whether circumstantial evidence about a foreign substance’s condition and location can show that it existed long enough to give the defendant constructive notice. It does not involve or discuss repeated complaints, photographic evidence, or a landlord–tenant context, nor does it analyze a failure to respond to such complaints as evidence of breach. While it affirms the general rule that a possessor is liable if it had actual or constructive notice and failed to remedy the hazard within a reasonable time, it does not specifically support the proposition about ignoring tenant complaints and photos demonstrating breach.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know… In the more usual case, however, the plaintiff attempts to establish the defendant’s negligence by showing that the foreign substance was present on the defendant’s premises for such a length of time that the defendant should have known about it.”

*Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc.*, 332 Ma.raw_text: *Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc.*, 332 Mass. 560, 563 (1955) (duty to remedy known hazard on premises)
*Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc.*, 332 Ma.proposition: Defendant’s failure to respond reasonably to repeated tenant complaints and photographic evidence of the hazardous condition further demonstrates a breach of her duty to exercise reasonable care. See *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973) (liability where defendant had actual or constructive notice of dangerous condition and failed to remedy within a reasonable time); *Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc.*, 332 Mass. 560, 563 (1955) (duty to remedy known hazard on premises).
*Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc.*, 332 Ma.support_reasoning: Gallagher directly discusses a premises owner’s duty, once a dangerous condition exists without the owner’s fault, to have a reasonable opportunity to learn of it and to remedy it, and holds the store could be found negligent for not discovering and removing a hazardous spill that should have been seen. That aligns with citing Gallagher for the general duty to remedy known (or reasonably knowable) hazards on the premises, which is what the proposition invokes alongside Oliveri; the case does not involve tenant complaints but does support the broader duty principle.
*Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc.*, 332 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant owed to customers a duty to keep the premises reasonably safe for their use. He, however, is not an insurer of safety. Where, without action for which he is responsible, a dangerous condition arises, the law allows him reasonable opportunity to become informed of the danger and to take measures to remedy it. He is not liable, in such a case, unless he is negligent in failing to inform himself and to take appropriate action.”

*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.raw_text: *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 639–40 (1996) (foreseeability of harm central to negligence analysis)
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.proposition: It was reasonably foreseeable to Defendant that leaving a narrow, untreated shoveled path to melt and refreeze into a sheet of ice on a heavily used walkway would result in slips, falls, and personal injuries to lawful visitors such as Plaintiff. See *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 639–40 (1996) (foreseeability of harm central to negligence analysis).
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of the opinion does not support the specific proposition that it was reasonably foreseeable that an untreated, narrow shoveled path would melt, refreeze, and cause slips and falls. Instead, the concurrence agrees that the plaintiff’s injuries in Poskus were not within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm, and it primarily discusses causation and foreseeability in the context of rejecting liability. While the case generally involves foreseeability in negligence, it is being cited here in a way that suggests support for foreseeability in the plaintiff’s favor, which is the opposite of what the court actually concluded.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.raw_text: *Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540, 544–45 (1982) (recognizing recovery for emotional distress accompanying physical injury)
*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.proposition: Plaintiff has experienced and continues to experience emotional distress, including anxiety, inconvenience, and a loss of enjoyment of life caused by the injuries and their consequences. See *Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540, 544–45 (1982) (recognizing recovery for emotional distress accompanying physical injury).
*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.support_reasoning: The proposition cites Payton for the availability of damages for emotional distress accompanying physical injury. In fact, Payton’s main holding is that Massachusetts does NOT allow recovery for negligently inflicted emotional distress in the absence of physical harm, and it only describes recovery for emotional distress with physical injury as traditional background (“parasitic” damages). The case does not create or focus on a rule about loss of enjoyment of life or similar distress when there is an underlying physical injury; rather, it restricts stand‑alone emotional distress claims without physical harm.
*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.relevant_excerpt: “Where plaintiffs have suffered directly inflicted personal injuries as a result of a defendant's negligence, courts have not been reluctant to allow recovery for emotional distress, occurring contemporaneously with those personal injuries, as an additional element of damages. … In these cases, recovery for emotional distress was allowed as a claim ‘parasitic’ to the ‘host’ claim of damages for negligently inflicted physical injuries. … We conclude that when recovery is sought for negligent, rather than intentional or reckless, infliction of emotional distress, evidence must be introduced that the plaintiff has suffered physical harm.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover fair and reasonable compensation for all past and future economic and non‑economic damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and loss of enjoyment of life. See G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence framework); *Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mountain Builders*, 441 Mass. 131, 136–37 (2004) (elements of negligence and damages).

*Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mountain Build.raw_text: *Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mountain Builders*, 441 Mass. 131, 136–37 (2004) (elements of negligence and damages)
*Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mountain Build.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover fair and reasonable compensation for all past and future economic and non‑economic damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and loss of enjoyment of life. See G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence framework); *Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mountain Builders*, 441 Mass. 131, 136–37 (2004) (elements of negligence and damages).
*Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mountain Build.case_name: Shantigar Foundation v. Bear Mountain Builders
*Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mountain Build.support_reasoning: The cited portion of Shantigar deals with comparative negligence under G.L. c. 231, § 85 and the allocation of fault among defendants, especially whether a settling tortfeasor should be included in the apportionment. It does not discuss the categories of recoverable damages in a negligence action (economic vs. non‑economic, pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, etc.), nor does it articulate a general rule that a plaintiff is entitled to ‘fair and reasonable compensation’ for all such damages. Thus, it does not support the specific damages proposition for which it is cited.
*Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mountain Build.relevant_excerpt: “The comparative negligence statute provides, in relevant part: ‘Contributory negligence shall not bar recovery in any action ... to recover damages for negligence ... if such negligence was not greater than the total amount of negligence attributable to the person or persons against whom recovery is sought, but any damages allowed shall be diminished in proportion to the amount of negligence attributable to the person for whose injury, damage or death recovery is made.’ ... ‘The combined total of the plaintiff’s negligence taken together with all of the negligence of all defendants shall equal one hundred per cent.’”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre‑judgment and post‑judgment interest as allowed by law, including G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
